sec.title: Summary of taxonomic organization
sec.p: When considering the phylogenetic results recovered by Svenson and Whiting (2009) the family-group, Liturgusidae, can not be considered a natural lineage. The name, stemming from the genus Liturgusa, could still apply to the Neotropical genera, but non-Neotropical genera would be taxonomically orphaned. The complexity of the polyphyly seen in Liturgusidae prevents simple taxonomic action since the higher-level relationships are still not robustly resolved to safely place non-Neotropical genera within established taxa. Therefore, these actions are avoided here as to not further destabilize the taxonomic organization. Listed here is the current taxonomic organization of the Neotropical Liturgusidae as well as a list of non-Neotropical genera that will eventually require placement within other family-groups. Interestingly, recent phylogenetic results stemming from new work on Neotropical mantises indicate that Gonatista Saussure, 1869 is not recovered with the Neotropical Liturgusidae, its fait currently unknown for higher-level placement (Rivera and Svenson, unpublished data).

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: I thank Roger Roy for his advisement, insights, and numerous contributions to this paper. Thanks to Julio Rivera for obtaining specimens, imaging Piza types in Brazil, providing an illustration of Liturgusa maya from Peru, and for translating the keys to Spanish to improve access to identification across most of the known range of Neotropical bark mantises. Thank you to Francesco Lombardo for his help searching for the types deposited in Italian museums. Thanks to Julián A. Salazar for sending images and measurement data for specimens held in Caldas University, Colombia. Thank you to Martin Stiewe for access to his private collection, allowing the close examination and performing measurements of his allotype amber specimen. Thanks to Nate Hardy for streamlining the handling of measurement data through creation of Python 2.7.5 scripts that compiled summary statistics and ranges for all species and measurement classes. For help databasing examined specimens and new CLEV material I thank Sridhar Rao, Rick Wherley, and Matthew Leister. Thanks to Joshua Maxwell of the Cleveland Institute of Art for his patience and continued efforts through numerous iterations of the diagnostic and habitus illustrations.

I thank those that helped me gain access to specimens, information, and images based in important collections in the United States, Europe, and South America including (in alphabetical order): Luca Bartolozzi, Natural History Museum, Zoological Section 'La Specola', University of Florence, Italy; George Beccaloni, The Natural History Museum, London; Stephan Blank, Senckenberg Deutsches Entomologisches Institut, Müncheberg, Germany; Stéphanie Boucher, Lyman Entomological Museum, McGill University, Quebec, Canada; David Furth, National Museum of Natural History, Smithsonian Institution, Washington, D.C.; Phillipe Grandcolas, Muséum national d’Histoire naturelle, Paris, France; David Grimaldi, American Museum of Natural History, New York, New York; Julieta Ledezma Arias, Museo de Historia Natural Noel Kempff Mercado, Santa Cruz, Bolivia; Peter Michalik, Ernst-Moritz-Arndt-Universität Greifswald, Germany; David Nickle, United States Department of Agriculture, Beltsville, Maryland; Michael Ohl, Museum für Naturkunde der Humboldt-Universität, Berlin, Germany; Norman Penny, California Academy of Sciences, San Francisco, CA; Julio Rivera, Museo de Entomología Klaus Raven Buller, Universidad Nacional Agraria La Molina, Lima, Peru and Royal Ontario Museum, Toronto, Canada; Roger Roy, Muséum national d’Histoire naturelle, Paris, France; Randall T Schuh, American Museum of Natural History, New York, New York; Kai Schütte, Biozentrum Grindel und Zoologisches Museum, Universität Hamburg, Germany; Peter Schwendinger, Muséum d’Histoire naturelle, Geneva, Switzerland; Zoë Simmons, Hope Entomological Collections, Oxford University Museum of Natural History, Oxford, United Kingdom; Jason Weintraub, Academy of Natural Sciences of Drexel University, Philadelphia, PA; Michael F. Whiting, Monte L. Bean Life Science Museum, Provo, Utah; Frank Wieland, Pfalzmuseum für Naturkunde – Pollichia Museum, Bad Dürkheim, Germany.
Thank you to those that have collected and contributed specimens for this project over the past decade including:
